Note

Procedurally – my apologies, though not my doing, as to the ads, which suddenly appeared on my WordPress site perhaps two years ago; ideally, I’d find a site without them, but only with…unlimited time:)!

*******************************************************

Substantively, and, in hopes to reach all levels of readers here, I’d say that….

A tiny handful of individuals in my “friends and family” circle will be glad to dive into all that I have written here, but no doubt that is rare.

With that in mind, the core essay is pretty breezy here in my mind, while appendices, as in a January 2023 blog of mine on Oakland, may seem like Jupiter – size-wise – or at least a cottage industry, but I would encourage your consideration of them if you want to get beyond the surface (aka the museum displays pictured below), see a few more interesting photos, etc.].

***********************************************************

In early March, 2023, I had a great time at the Idaho Black History Museum (IBHM) whose structure, seen below, was moved to this site from a nearby spot where it had been the historically Black St. Paul Baptist Church….

My two visits to the museum came during a short visit to Boise. [But long enough to begin to learn to ditch a “z” in saying the city’s name, as it is pronounced “BOY-see”!]

It is easily found within the city’s Julia Davis Park, neighboring its bigger cultural siblings of the Idaho State Museum and the Boise Art Museum, with the State museum seen to the left in this image of a western entry to the Park….

I would guess that most people are likely to see 20-30 minutes as a reasonable amount of time to experience the museum’s narrative kiosks and display cases, with this view of early March showing maybe 70% of the one room for the museum…..

It is definitely a small cultural attraction, but one where it is easy to be exposed to big ideas and, in my case at least, different perspectives, thanks largely to Phillip Thompson….

…the head of the board for the museum and its director.

While his perspective certainly offers education on the sadness and tragedies of the past experienced by people of color, his greater emphasis is on taking advantage of opportunities today, using Idaho’s favorable story – to a very large extent as he sees it – for Blacks.

I would see both of us as having a largely positive view of Black survival, and “thrival”, in our nation – of celebrating “Black Joy” (in nodding to a more common term in recent years) and Black achievement; anywhere I do that is very much thanks in large part to my parents, now deceased, working for a number of years at Karamu Theater, an interracial arts organization in Cleveland, Ohio, and people still recalling how much they enjoyed its interracialism as well as its pursuit of Black artistry.

Still, I am deeply rooted in an orientation which exists much more on the left, of highlighting ongoing systemic racism, allowing at its most energetic end for campaigns such as those which seek reparations for enslavement and other pursuits which….might not be seen as right – on the Right:).

I did not walk away from the museum (hereinafter referred to at times as IBHM or the BHM?) with any markedly changed views of America’s situation as to racial and social justice, but the conversations there were a reminder to listen deeply, often to things you do not want to hear, as long as you have some legitimate sense that those who voice them want constructive and respectful dialogue, whatever their positions.

While there are a few reasons for any place evolving in its own particular way, Phillip Thompson sees an earlier decision in what was then Idaho Territory as key for everything that follows.

When the Territory was eight years old, in 1871, it disallowed segregation in schools, as noted in what may be the second and perhaps key paragraph of this first “narrative board” which I saw at the IBHM…..

That early move echoes to this day in Mr. Thompson’s mind, when incomes for Blacks in Idaho have in recent years been…shall we say….a very unexpected percentage of White incomes in Idaho, enough that I will let readers guess that “number” and note it in an appendix to this writing.

Shortly after I came into the museum for my first of two visits there, I heard this statistic, and I rarely use the term “mind-blowing”, so I’ll just say…it’s halfway to mind-blowing.

Once three of us who were visiting and communicating with Mr. Thompson knew that… at least in very recent times – Black incomes in Idaho were proportionally the highest of Black incomes in any state, he went on to ask me and the two white ladies who had walked in to the display area if we could guess what state has recently had the second-highest income for Blacks, and he responded that it is Wyoming, in regards to which he said….in essence….”and you know what?”….adding that it was, like present-day Idaho, also part of “Idaho Territory” early on, as seen in the map within the board below; to be sure, Wyoming is basically the rectangle to the lower right of Idaho…..

I will once again be coy and give you a chance to guess Black incomes as a percentage of white incomes in Wyoming, directing you to the same appendix if you cannot wait to pass go, or the like! [Appendix One: Black incomes as a percentage of White incomes in Idaho and Wyoming].

No doubt, one quickly learns that American-born Blacks in Idaho are (drum roll)….around .75 percent of the state’s population, or at least work force, so it is easy to throw at least one critique Mr. Thompson’s way, that this is a case of too few Blacks historically or today to excite antipathy and oppression.

[And since we were talking in a former church, it was even easier to remember the famous Bible passage on the response of ancient Egyptians to a growing number of Israelites in their midst that “the more they afflicted them, the more they multiplied and grew. And they were grieved because of the children of Israel.”]

Here, I can at least bet that Mr. Thompson will have responses to counter-arguments like this within a recently finished study in which his research was a critical part of overall findings and conclusions from Professor Rama K. Malladi, of the University of California at Dominguez Hills; one of the key components of their article was responding to why the incomes of Black Idahoans are as relatively high as they are. Outside of that writing, one of Phillip’s rejoinders to the sense that “oh, there aren’t that many Blacks in the state anyways, so they’ll be more accepted” is to note that two of the worst states for Black economic outcomes – North and South Dakota – also have….small numbers of Blacks.

Thompson, a Boisean six generations – strong on his mother’s side, feels impelled to share all of the opportunities which the city and the state have afforded to Black people, one example being the pioneering leadership status of his mother, Cherie Buckner-Webb, seen here…..

[courtesy of Phillip Thompson]

Her distinctions include being the first elected African-American state legislator in Idaho history and the state’s first African-American woman legislator. And the displays he has created reinforce Idaho as a place of opportunity from the beginning (1863, territorially) through its “modern era”, which he dates as beginning with statehood in 1890.

Perhaps the first figure to be honored at the museum from the state’s territorial days is Lewis Walker….

[courtesy of Phillip Thompson]

…a Maryland native who headed west and became successful as a barber, real estate owner and more, especially in his adopted hometown – the one-time mining center of Silver City – from 1864 onwards.

Another remarkable contemporary was George Washington Blackman, born in Kentucky, quite possibly as an enslaved person, and attracted to Idaho’s mining opportunities in the 1870’s.

His name adorns the Idaho mountain Blackman’s Peak, among other natural landmarks and you can read a little more from this museum sign….

…as well as hopefully have easier access to the sign’s QR code right here, for a short writing on name origins you probably would not expect, from him and others….

Moving on to the early 1900’s, one of the IBHM displays highlights Erma Hayman (1907-2009)….

[source: https://www.ermahaymanhouse.org%5D

….a long-time resident of Boise’s River Street neighborhood, whose house is being preserved and reopened just a few blocks west of the museum, looking a bit lonely as seen from the south within an area sprouting new developments, but still with an attractive white fence enlarging what is meant to become a well-used events space….

…and seen from across Ash Street where it was once part of a lively early 20th-century block of new Boiseans from places including Japan, the Basque region of Spain, Croatia and more….

The city’s Department of Arts and History is overseeing the preservation and reuse of the house as a history and cultural center, advocating on one municipal site for its rebirth with the main point that “[m]ost [of the] structures from the early days of the River Street Neighborhood have been lost, and like so many areas populated by immigrants, Black Americans, and members of the working class, its stories have gone largely overlooked”.

The diversity of this particular neighborhood, with echoes today in the Boise area, will be fleshed out a bit further in a second appendix. For many….the “A” word absolutely assures (think of an “a” synonym for boredom)….but my second “Appendix” will offer some history once again and a slice of Boise’s present – both unexpected in terms of diversity, at least from a “bigger city” lens – and a few pictures as well. [See Appendix Two, “Ida-hospitality from Victorian days to today”.]

In short though, Director Thompson brings such highpoints of Idaho into his historical argument that the state, overall, has allowed equal opportunity to more than just White Christians.

While Phillip Thompson may be the best salesman for his native city and state, he also portrays shameful moments in state history, such as moments of power for the Klu Klux Klan, as suggested here, where you may be able to access a QR-coded article [while a pay-wall may be in place]; in its last two paragraphs, the article notes a few aspects as to the KKK almost coming to power in Twin Falls, Idaho:

Another exhibit sign in part highlights a sadly successful effort to push out Chinese immigrants, summarized in the paragraph towards the bottom left:

Returning to the Klan, Thompson is decisive in displaying a Klan robe discovered in Silver City, Idaho (ironically, as noted earlier, a very positive place for Idaho territory pioneer Lewis Walker)…..

…and it was one of several launch-pads for his critique of what might be considered a liberal/left approach to history. He passionately commented that if people are going to complain about white supremacy in our day, they cannot at the same time be against showing such an ugly artifact, as otherwise, there is no visible basis for their rant.

In an overlapping light, he spoke of what he sees as an “outrage machine” on the left, and one of his main rhetorical questions during my time at the IBHM, was – not to me but in reference to various expressions – “are you just expressing your opinions, or are you communicating conclusions based on facts?”

Phillip’s critique of the left finds a parallel in how he perceives other big cities in the Northwestern region of the U.S. He shared at one point that a number of people in Boise “will compare Boise to Portland, and that’s not appropriate….they should compare Boise to Salt Lake City”, this observation at least in part because of Portland’s liberalism, in relation to which he added “who wants to go there anyways?” – that query with the sense of its being overrun with unhoused people.

These were by no means his only critical words, and in the spirit of “brevity is the soul of wit” – so my wit is not so dim!! (at least to keep this core essay shorter:)) – please see yet two more appendices, respectively on his views (#3 below) and mine (#4).

As stated above, I would hope you are getting a good read minus appendices, but to the extent you want to travel vicariously, dig into dialogue and/or see a few photos, please check out those additions to this writing:)!

I do not want to leave my greatest concern here for “appendices” though.

It is that the message of needing to move beyond the victimhood of Blacks – from a Black person – can be hijacked by White extremists and, with any such messaging, we will be that much closer to a return to proto-fascism in 2024 and beyond. I am glad that I raised this issue with Mr. Thompson, if in somewhat different words, and felt reassured that he began to articulate his own opposition to the farthest “Right” [or should I say Wrong] in America, saying that January 6, 2021 represented the first non-peaceful transfer of power in our history. [Phillip later clarified his sense that either extreme – the farthest right or left – is destructive to the American fabric.]

I am so glad that I walked into the IBHM, and, among other things, saw its take on the march of humanity and of justice, including a timeline of race-related history in the “Gem State”, two examples being that of 1921….

….and 1961….

In many years to come, I hope that Mr. Thompson and the IBHM continue to thrive and grow and be part of a larger dialogue towards an American exceptionalism that he treasures, even if our respective definitions of that…beacon on a hill may differ.

The greatest goal here in a way is a respectful communication following active listening, and with much more to come. I am blessed that it can be within the fascination and sometimes joy of history, and discovery of new places, as in my time in Boise, Idaho in March, 2023.

Appendix 1: Black incomes as a percentage of White incomes in Idaho and Wyoming

During the March visit noted above, Phillip Thompson pointedly noted the percentage level of Black incomes in relation to White incomes, saying it was 105%. Very shortly thereafter, as written above, he shared the same type of figure for Wyoming – where he said Black incomes were 95% of White ones.

These conclusions are based on a study focusing on the years 2017-2019 and put out in July 2020, and actually, Department of Labor statistics for Idaho sweeten the cherry on the cake a tiny bit, saying that Blacks earned $106, not $105, for a White worker’s $100.

At the Labor Department site here, you can look these figures up by cursoring down to “Idaho” and “Wyoming” respectively: https://www.dol.gov/agencies/ofccp/about/data/earnings/race-and-ethnicity.

Appendix 2: Ida-hospitality from Victorian days to today

I would echo what Mr. Thompson says in addition to his pro-Idaho history argument, that the state by no means has an unbroken happy history as to newcomers, and, today, people on the left such as myself are conscious of the far right, especially in the far north/Panhandle area of Idaho. As I landed “out west” in the Spokane airport on February 24 for four days in that Eastern Washington city, I saw the ad below reminding one of the proximity of Northern Idaho….

….and made a crack to myself that we (or WA state:) were also close to the far right.

With that notable disclaimer of blue planeteers too often turning their noses at the thought of ye olde Potato State, it was fascinating, as well as interesting to me as a historical tour guide in Philadelphia, to see the close proximity of three distinct spaces that very much speak to an Idaho welcome in the late 19th century, the early 1900’s and today.

While many engaging spaces in Boise are too far apart from each other for a walking tour, unlike so much of Central Philadelphia, I’ll bet that THESE three spaces have likely ALREADY formed a great walk, or could.

From north to south, they begin and end with key points in Jewish history for Idaho, and, in between, with somber as well as celebratory stops in the history of a very new immigrant group in this part of the American West.

Shortly before coming to Boise, I learned, not only as a lover of history, but as a Jew, that….surprisingly….Idaho lays claim to being the first state to have a practicing Jewish governor. His name was Moses Alexander and his American life began after he emigrated to the United States from his native Germany in 1867, while still in his early teens. His success, both in Chillicothe, Missouri, where he did well in business as well as becoming the Mayor, and later as a store owner in Boise, led him to the Mayor’s office of Idaho’s capital, for two non-consecutive two-year terms, and, almost a generation later, to the governor’s office in his adopted city, from 1915-1919.

All of that led me to want to see his burial site in Boise’s Morris Hill Cemetery, based in an area of town known as “The Bench” – an area label which works for me, given that its name is remindful of the Yiddish verb “Bentsch”, for “to bless” (as in saying a blessing) and it definitely contains the most notable scene of Jewish worship in the region – the synagogue and related properties of Congregation Ahavah Beth Israel.

Not so far from that Judaic landmark, I saw the family plot including Alexander….

….and within it, the grave stones for him and his wife Helena seen here….

From there, it is perhaps a five-minute walk at the most to a southern point in the cemetery where Morris Hill continues to tell the story of a place that affords opportunity for immigrants, in a cluster of tombs for Bosnian Moslems who have been resettled in Idaho, and with some very recent dates of passing at times, including the last two years. Taking it from Phillip Thompson, Boise might be the most successful city for refugee resettlement in the United States, or at least very close to that summit.

While I am currently deferring the inclusion of photos which I took of particular stones, these individuals “have names like….” (as journalist Charles Kuralt might have said in his televised American travel forays years ago)…..Alomerović, Hasanbegović, Rahimić and Suljagić (keeping it wiki-respectful there and not using actual names seen in Morris Hill Cemetery).

This was easily within view of a very historic synagogue structure, seen here…..

for a congregation built up in part by Moses Alexander, whose good fortune in the world of department stores was key in most likely garnering direct support from at least two legendary donors for its construction – Marshall Field of Chicago and Levi Strauss of San Francisco – but at least their companies have been cited as contributors.

And while one might instantly think “San Francisco” if asked….What city has the oldest continuously used synagogue building west of the Mississippi? ….Boiseans widely believe that you just saw the answer above, from what I’ve gathered, partly because two legendary (and clearly older) congregations in San Francisco built new structures in the 20th century.

Would that the beautiful 1890’s Moorish-style structure, with its intimate interior seen here…..

….was “in situ” as preservationists say for structures, paintings, etc., at their original locations, but thank God as well that it was moved uphill to the Bench in 2003, from 11th & State Streets near the heart of Boise.

I want to thank select staff members (and “CABI” members) for their wonderful hospitality and assistance in this brief look at “CABI”, whether on site when I visited in March or through e-mails since then. They include but were fortunately not limited to Rabbi Dan Fink, Roy Ledesma, Kali Cusimano and Joanna Jost and I wish all the best to them and their synagogue family in the new Jewish year of 5784 which began on September 15, and well beyond.

Appendix 3. Further views of IBHM’s director Phillip Thompson

While I sensed in my brief communications with Phillip Thompson that he does not want to necessarily be the center of attention here, he has deep beliefs, and the enthusiasm to not just dole out history but offer it in a spirit of advocacy for what he sees as a positive world view. Had I not had a great experience inside the former structure for St. Paul’s Missionary Baptist Church (now “IBHM”) in Boise, I would have still believed that the views here need to be part of a respectful struggle towards a better world.

Easy enough, perhaps, but, as far as the “hard listening” I alluded to above, at least a tiny handful of statements below will drive some people up their respective walls, and believe me – I am chomping at the bit (not a Western rodeo bit either:)) to respond to a few of them, but…..if each of us expects to be judged fully and not castigated on the basis of one or two statements, we owe that to almost anyone else.

That does not include….a handful of….putative leaders, people who do not actually care about regular people, etc. [Name a name or names as you wish here and now in 2023.]. Even with them, it is about determining the roots of their expressions, with compassion towards the anxiety and fear that precedes intense tribalism, hate and the like.

The basis for discussion in my mind should be….Do you really think the person on the other side of the ideological table wants to do you harm, or just feels differently about an issue, and perhaps really deeply, as deeply as you might feel??

In a nutshell, one might say that Mr. Thompson’s views are: not to dwell on historical sufferings of the past, but to focus on present-day opportunity, while at the same time telling the very hard truth of parts of history such as deep blemishes covered above like Klan dominance at brief points of Idaho history.

In addition, he volunteered at one point that “only America has used race to divide [its people]”, or at least more so than other countries…saying that “we’ve taken it to the next level”.

No doubt he is conscious of his Blackness and feels that race is clearly one attribute for a person but focuses more so on “opportunity” broadly stated. He notes that from “a data-driven perspective, capitalism has been the greatest tool for improving the lives of humans”.

One of the very first things I heard him say after I entered the museum was that “the Idaho experience is anomalous but should be instructive – that it is best for government to get out of the way, and people will flourish”. In addition, one of the very first things I heard him say….when I visited the museum for a second time, was his sharing with an older White couple that “[m]y grandfather was the first black graduate of Boise State and it wasn’t because of some herculean effort, it was just a non-issue…..I wish more people would take more notice of our hands-off approach”.

Later, he said to me that “I believe…most things can be boiled down to economics, not race” and that “race is a byproduct of economics”.

He reinforced this by saying that in terms of friction points in American history, that “mass immigration stresses resources – whatever the incoming group in question, and can lead to the charge that “ ‘you’re taking our jobs’ ”. It seems definite that he would bolster this by pointing to the violent reaction to high numbers of Chinese entering Idaho in the late 1800’s.

And, whatever my views, I could easily underscore this by pointing to violence against Irish Catholics in the 1840’s here in Philadelphia, and can at least theorize that the economics of the “age of exploration” in Renaissance Europe lead to a sense of Europeans as superior to peoples of color – as a rationale for harvesting the resources of the Americas. [Pardon if you will my polite language here, and the irony of referring to the “Renaissance” in this case, as that label so often symbolizes enlightenment.]

These….dry, non-emotional…observations [or so I believe:)] can give way to Phillip’s critique of the Left that it will heavily, and too emotionally, scratch the past itches of our societies, instead of being fact-based.

One local example, for him, was that of speaking to some students at Boise State University a few years ago when the discussion swung to micro-aggressions – a concept with which he was not familiar. This recollection led him in part to say to me that there can be “too much encouragement for students to share their feelings, partly [in regards to such] ‘micro-aggressions’ “. In relation to that and on at least two other occasions during our brief exchanges, he would say “that’s what a therapist is for”, i.e., that these are personal issues, at least overall, and should not be conflated or exploded on a public stage.

At one point, he said to me….”What is this about micro-aggressions? My [forebears] were worried about acts like lynchings”…..meaning, for him — actual major aggressions. This is a reminder of two themes to which he would return – first his belief that there ARE actual problems in the nation and the world, sometimes serious, and secondly an essentially positive view of America ca. 2023, and especially Idaho.

Elsewhere in my visits, in discussion with a Boise area woman and me, he said “slavery has been normal in a number of societies throughout history and if you are opposed to it you should not talk about what went on at one time but fight actual slavery still going on today”. This was echoed in his offering the insight at one point that the “killings of women in Kurdistan are a REAL example of a [violent] patriarchy…. not [whatever goes on in] the US”, and he raised this example in connection with a woman who as of early March was hoping to become a resettled refugee in Boise.

On the national as well as home front, he made the point in conversation with me later, that he does see problems that exist, environmentally for example, and does something about them, with his emphasis there on not using plastic wherever possible. Additionally, he bikes at times from his North End neighborhood to IBHM, largely for the “cardio”, but knowing it also happens to be good for the environment.

The FACTS for him, if heavily Ida-centric, one might say, are largely that we live, in much of the United States, within a positive framework, partly in terms of overall health and actual lower levels of violence – as compared with points in the past – [despite the pain of seemingly daily news in such regards]. I noted that this conclusion is very remindful of that of Steven Pinker, who has argued that the world, on aggregate, is very much an improving one in recent decades as well as centuries, thanks to the benefits wrought through technology and capitalism.

Within Boise itself, Phillip revels in the blessings he feels within his hometown. In part, he looks at his boyhood neighborhood of the North End, and feels that for him and his daughter, they are better off than 90% of humans, etc., within “the greatest country ever…in a period of lower violence overall [and] with an abundance of amenities” a viewpoint which I was reminded of one day as I looked down from a balcony at a Whole Foods market just a few blocks from IBHM….

Phillip said that “from my mom’s generation to me to my daughter” that there have been many improvements” and added that his daughter, who turned 12 this past March, “has only known a positive world, including going to a school that he helped to found. In correspondence after my visit, he wrote, using the nickname of “Junior” for her and spelling out….the “N” word – that a “case in point at her current school [was when] a child – who was [a] non-white child but not Black either – called her a N- … I received a call [about this incident] and when I asked Jr about it she said ‘I don’t even know what that means’ — her life is that good”. Last year, for him, that positive state was underscored by her interviewing the mayor of Boise, with his observation that “that degree of access for my kid is unfathomable”.

His positive spirit as to his city and state can easily be paired with his buoyant feeling as to at least one strand of red, white and blue – the idea of American exceptionalism. He offered that he is “not by nature a patriotic person,” but added that “I’ve become more patriotic as I’ve grown older”, especially in regards to the widespread idea of the exceptional nature of the United States in its allowance for changes in our governmental system. He later added that “the architects [of our Constitution] included a means to append and correct their vision [with their] being fully aware it was a process in order to achieve a ‘more perfect union’ ”.

He says that it is “mind-blowing to have that degree of humility….[and a sense that…] we’re not going to get it right the first time” but “we’re going to leave a system in place that allows us to get this better.” He enthusiastically concluded that “the exceptionalism is found in admitting fallibility….that’s HUGE!” and added that “that’s why I’ve become a gung-ho American exceptionalist”.

From America’s self-correction mechanisms, one could move to his fervent sense that Black History commemorations should definitely be corrected. In short, he says they are often way too negative – or narrowly-focused on stereotypical areas of Black achievement – the former very much in reference to….enslavement, the latter regarding sports and ENTERTAINMENT.

In an e-mail of March 8, he wrote that “US Black history is far more than the notion of “ills perpetrated against,” although that is part of it….[and] more important are the contributions and uplifting aspects of Black history. He readily shared something I had never read – that the “first Black man in America was Juan Garrido, the Portuguese conquistador, contrary to the thought that the first Blacks arrived on [American] shores as slaves [in] 1619”.

A Black conquistador who may be Garrido is seen in the image below from a fascinating but undated manuscript known as the Codex Azcatitlan, written by unknown authors sometime between about 1550-1700. While the Codex focuses on what is today Mexico, Garrido’s footsteps include time in Florida when he served under Juan Ponce de Leon.

[https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Juan_Garrido_Azcatitlan.jpg]

Phillip sees Garrido as a positive counter to “those who commercially exploit what they see as reflecting Black history [and] seem to view us in regards to entertainment, sports, and ills that have been committed against us, diminishing the vast contributions not of only those that were remarkable, but the vast majority of blacks who don’t fit into these categories”.

He wrote in regards to a recent video “streaming subscription” that “I chuckled [as to its] vast numbers of recommendations for celebrating Black culture, but [felt that they were] overwhelmingly not something I would want my [12-year old daughter] to emulate or identify as…Black culture”.

Later, he texted that, among many who convey Black experiences, there is a “lack of effort to examine/explore/emulate communities that defy and excel in the face of challenges” and that “they act as if that doesn’t exist or at the least they fail to acknowledge and let these successes be known”. He capped this by saying that “they are not trying to remedy [misunderstanding of Blacks, etc.], but “simply trying to exploit” more dramatic and negative stories.

I am hopeful that what follows in terms of Phillip’s conclusions, etc., does not itself seem too dramatic or negative. At the same time, I realize that for many Blacks and White progressives, some of the world views above and below will be simply untenable for discussion. I hope that all readers agree, at least in theory if not in all instances, that we must engage in deep listening – to the largely “unpalatable” if not untenable.

Before I offer five examples in this regard , from my listening in Boise, I will direct readers to the next appendix and a segment where I very briefly comment on the limits of tough listening, knowing I cannot assess that for people of color – or for anyone else, but also believing that there are many people like me who want understanding and peace. People will of course ask – when is outrageous too outrageous to even listen to? or….when is a thought so grossly offensive that you should not be part of a discussion?

If you are beginning to feel such questions, I would…very much regret your exiting the IBHM freeway here, prior to the final paragraphs of this section, with the next access road being….Appendix 4:).

Moving just below from less sharp to…too sharp? – it all depends on your viewpoints….I’ll present five basic points from Phillip Thompson.

I’ll start with a point of agreement between Phillip, me and a white lady from Boise who I had noted as a visitor to the museum. It was very much in reference to slavery in America, but could apply to a number of tragedies, themes, etc., and was simply the…cliche?…. that you should not look at the past only through YOUR contemporary lense but as someone in the 1800’s, etc., would have thought about it.

While that may sound easy at first, I believe it can be overtaken in certain classrooms because of deep-seated beliefs that delving into perspectives of “the time” means that one agrees with vastly immoral acts as many more people see them today.

Secondly, Phillip is (not surprisingly?)…not in favor of reparations to Black Americans for slavery. I personally – and without effort I’d say – “rate this” as a widely held position in the U.S., apart from whether or not one would see it as moral, immoral, insensitive etc.

He feels it is “a false premise that you can right a historical wrong” or “that those who are going to pay [reparations] are guilty of that historical wrong” and added that “you are giving money to those who are not the victims of the stated wrong”. Both he and the Boise woman noted here discussed the aspect that once you pay reparations, that will not end the debate as they thought some defenders of reparations have implied but that various people will still want to raise the issue. [In a text of July 21, Phillip added that “other than [in] cases of known theft of property (reparations seem) like an ill-conceived notion, literally throwing money at a problem without addressing or fixing it”.]

“Number 3” here, at a somewhat harder or slightly more cutting level, sees Phillip at one point in early March reflecting the sensitivity of many White Americans that they are being labeled racists, and no doubt I would affirm that this is at least a valid concern in the minds of those people. Overlapping with what I wrote earlier, people are complex, and we cannot know the fullness of their lives by a few statements, wordings which seem prejudiced to us, non-incendiary to them, etc.

His pushback as to the label of racism was directly addressed to progressives increasingly believing that you are racist if you are not actively anti-racist. Here, he said that by that logic, people who do not actively fight the trafficking of children are therefore in support of trafficking of children.

Number 4 on the sharpness meter will be a snoozer for some, and make others squirm every time we hear it. It is an “old saw” in my book, and when the Boise woman offered it – saying that “not all slave owners were bad”, Phillip did not seem to respond unfavorably, while I did not follow up as to his thoughts here.

It is very likely that he migrated to Cleveland in 1921, in which case he would not have been on the ground floor of founding Elizabeth, so assuming he is still its name-creator, questions and gaps in that regard should be filled in – e.g., did it simply have a different name or a place-holder kind of name, from April 1919 until he came on the scene?

A wider story of keeping names alive?

Three members of Elizabeth Baptist Church in Cleveland have been among many whose lives can tell just part of one of its stories – of often being founded or strengthened by individuals from the South, with Alabama perhaps being most prominent in this regard.

Seen here, they are Rubye Jones, standing next to Willie Ligon at the left and Pearl Ellington at the right…

[November 3, 2019 at the time of an EBC service; photo courtesy of Rubye Jones]

In brief, on each of these three EBC members….

Rubye Jones has been a towering presence in this writing, certainly the most generous assistant to my inquiries, and is now nearly a 61-year member of Elizabeth since coming to Cleveland from Tuskegee, Alabama and beginning to attend EBC in September, 1962.

Willie Ligon, who I briefly interviewed by phone when he was 100, was born in 1918 in Tuskegee and has passed away, I believe at the age of 101 in 2020. He came up to Cleveland from Alabama in 1940 and joined EBC in the 1960’s, grateful then and forever after for the supportive conversations he had with Reverend Fred Hall, as I write in a 2019 writing [noted already in this post] at https://silverstravels.wordpress.com/2019/12/19/clevelands-elizabeth-baptist-church-an-historical-essay/.

Pearl Ellington was born in Hardaway, Alabama, just west of Fort Davis, attended St. Mark Baptist Church, also in Elizabeth Baptist Church’s community of Fort Davis and came to Cleveland in 1946. She is 98, currently resides in Detroit, and keeps connections with EBC, the life-long church of her son Charles Ellington II, who is now 75. [Endnote 8]

Rubye Jones, Pearl Ellington and Willie Ligon are among so many Cleveland-area residents who emigrated from the South, starting with the greatest wave of the Great Migration – from perhaps 1919-1945, and continuing thereafter for a while as that wave was still breaking.

The Southern-born Black men and women and children who moved up to Cleveland, Detroit, Pittsburgh and many more cities brought not only an urge to leave the South, but – for many – a passionate connection to it, and it is quite likely – based on my brief exploration here – that their Southern possessions included a number of church names as well.

I am guessing this is a well-known fact, actually, but….am still hoping to reach historians who can attest to that, or correct that notion – as this “goes to post”.

While I did not prove that this was the case as wiser heads have trained me to try to do, I would guess that many Southern names dotted the new settlements of Northern towns and cities, partly because of that very human desire to keep some of a homeland alive.

Today, for many students of the Great Migration, the number one book is The Warmth of Other Suns, by Isabel Wilkerson. It is often built around particular individuals and organizations and their experience in moving North and elsewhere, largely to industrializing cities whose jobs drew them in – very much in the Midwest and the Northeast, and perhaps with the West Coast as the next biggest magnet for them.

One organization Ms. Wilkerson returns to on a number of pages is the “Monroe Club”, which actually sprouted up in a multiple cities including Chicago, thriving at least for a few decades on individuals who left Monroe, Louisiana, so, in a broad sense, groups like this definitely preserved a hometown name.

In what I think was a brief but meaningful survey by me of readings on the Great Migration, I would say that the closest approaches to the “planet” of transferring an actual church name to a new church up North came with a summary comment on some of the new churches in Chicago in the late 19-teens through the 1920’s and, separately, an example from Cleveland.

One brief Great Migration survey said that some Southern congregations moved to Chicago as a group, keeping both their customs and their group identity. The desire to keep alive the intimacy and liveliness of Southern church life displayed itself in many small prayer groups – which would meet in a migrant’s home – and storefront churches throughout Chicago’s South Side. [Endnote 9.]

Returning to Cleveland, one sees the same phenomena. Here, I’ll refer to two earlier periods, with one naturally being the era of the Great Migration. Secondly, as the following comes from a book of the 1970’s, it is dated in at least its use of the label “Negro” but the writing – A Ghetto Takes Shape / Black Cleveland, 1870-1930, by Kenneth Kusmer – remains a major source for Black history in Cleveland.

Kusmer writes that…

“Conspicuous among the new churches were the numerous storefront congregations of the Holiness and Spiritualist sects and the poorer Baptists. In the 1920’s, lower Central and Scovill avenues were dotted with the makeshift edifices of these congregations. These churches, with their personalized, informal services and fervid religious emotionalism, appealed to many of the lower-class Negro migrants from the South. Some of these new churches were able to preserve the congregations of southern communities almost intact. For example, one black minister, Charles C. Ailer, came to Cleveland from Alabama with his congregation and founded Zion Hill Baptist Church. This type of institutional “transplanting” gave a measure of continuity to the lives of southern migrants, and helped smooth the path of their adjustment to urban society”. [Endnote 10.]

At other times, similarly, those who arrived from the South began churches which “replicated Delta practices” – with this quote referring to how Chicago’s Black life was often flavored by Mississippi migrants – but they did not instantly set these congregations in motion, doing so after the trial and error of joining – in brief – the wrong type of church for them.

This was likely to be that of earlier or “Old Settlers” Black churches, and in Cleveland, these included ones which were partly “upper-crust” in terms of the income of a number of members. Two in this regard, with all the pride of their longevity, are Mount Zion Congregational Church and St. Andrew’s Episcopal, respectively established in 1864 and in 1891, well before the huge stream of Blacks coming up from the South.

Kusmer writes that “[n]either church was interested in accepting working-class Negroes as members, and most recent migrants from the South would have found the staid, dignified services that both provided rather uninviting”. Kusmer notes that the content of sermons at those two elite institutions and more working-class churches was similar, and he says that “[i]t was the highly emotional form, not the content, of the typical Baptist sermon that the black upper class found distasteful”. [Endnote 11]

Today, Elizabeth Baptist Church might be largely unrecognizable to its first members, partly because of its own greater affluence since the day when – like so many other churches – it started in someone’s home. It has changed in many small ways, including the hard work of so many members over the generations, and so many new names since its founding in 1919.

It does, at the same time, include a number of 3rd and 4th generation members if not deeper familial roots and its name most definitely remains.

Exploring the origins of that name and many other anecdotes and stories can be a tool for understanding this church community and deciding what to keep from the past and how to change and evolve. Besides those “practical” reasons, it is always time, in a way, to honor people such as Brother Lewis Tate who helped to achieve new beginnings.
